title: Antinomies of Realism, 29–­31. For Amy Holzapafel, too, this uneasy interplay between subjective and objective impulses is the key to understanding theatrical realism. In her pathbreaking reappraisal of nineteenth-​century playwrights like Ibsen, Strindberg, and Hauptmann, she argues that by the end of the century, realism, far from being a naive mode of mirror-​like reflection, had become “a process of making visible the act of seeing
